trial_identification.studytitle: An investigation of the clinical utility of the electronic toilet top bidet for use with Australian nursing home residents and staff.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: For nursing home residents, does consistent use of the electronic wash and dry toilet top bidet clean more effectively after voiding bladder or bowels and reduce bacteriurea, incontinence associated dermatitis and cost of incontinence products than usual toileting care?

conditions.healthcondition: Cleaning after toilet use in nursing home residents

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of infection and infectious agents

interventions.interventions: The electronic, wash-and-dry toilet top bidet will be used by nursing home staff after each toileting episode for residents. The bidet used in this investigation is a toilet seat replacement that provides a heated seat; two retractable, self cleaning nozzles that provide a thermostatically controlled warm water wash of the perineum or perianal area after voiding bladder or bowels; and a warm air blower to dry the user after washing. The bidet is operated by a remote control unit. The bidet to be used is the Coway BA-08. Effects of use of the bidet on cleanliness, bacteriurea, incontinence-associated dermatitis and other effects will be observed over a 12-week intervention period.
interventions.comparator: No bidet, usual toileting care which consists of wiping with toilet paper, washing the perineum with damp face washers/proprietary wipes and/or application of topical emollients where indicated.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Nursing home residents will be effectively cleaned after voiding bladder or bowels assessed by nursing home care staff.
Urine bacterial colony counts compared to baseline and controls
Acceptability of bidet for nursing home residents, assessed on 5-point Likert scale.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Rates of incontinence associated dermatitis as assessed by the Incontinence Associated Dermatitis (IAD) Scale (Borchert et al 2010).
Non-dietary aperient use in comparison to baseline as recorded in the resident aged care file.
Cost of incontinence products used, taken from financial data provided by participating facilities' accounting departments.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 12 weeks pre-trial, 12 weeks during trial, 12 weeks of corresponding period in previous financial year.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: a. Permanent resident of an accredited Australian Residential Aged Care Facility b. Require assistance to toilet c. Have capacity to consent or have proxy consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Have any condition that would contraindicate use of bidet, on the recommendation of facility staff or resident's GP

trial_design.concealment: Resident-participants are chosen by staff of participating nursing homes. Reasons for selection form part of study data. Concealment is not possible for use of device. Number of participants is determined by number of bidets purchased by participating nursing homes. Estimated sample size: 48
trial_design.designfeatures: this is a non-randomised, pre and post controlled comparison, pragmatic pilot trial
trial_design.statisticalmethods: Descriptive statistics will compare frequencies and t-tests and chi square will determine group differences. Differences between groups over time (including colony counts of bacteria in urine)will be analysed using analysis of co-variance. Focus group: line-by-line analysis of verbatim transcribed data Cost utilisation: descriptive statistics

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This proposed investigation will build upon a previous feasibility study to explore acceptance, use, clinical utility (including effects of bidet use on asymptomatic bacteria in urine) and associated costs of the electronic toilet top wash-and-dry bidet by residents and staff of Australian residential aged care facilities, as a method of improving the toileting experience for older, frail and/or cognitively impaired residents of aged care facilities and staff.
